author: By Eric Schmitt and Madeleine Ngo
title: Afghan Pilots Who Sought Safety in Uzbekistan Transfer to U.S. Base
description: Taliban leaders have been pressuring the Uzbek government to turn over the pilots, who fear for the safety of themselves and their families.
content: WASHINGTON — An initial group of Afghan pilots who flew themselves and their family members to safety in Uzbekistan aboard Afghan Air Force aircraft were transferred to a U.S. military base in the United Arab Emirates on Sunday, according to the office of Representative August Pfluger, which has been in contact with one of the pilots and his wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us About Your Second Pandemic Summer
description: Did life return to normal? Or did Delta foil your plans?
content: In June, as days stretched long, it really seemed as if the pandemic in the United States was waning. Mask came off. Restaurants and bars reopened. Americans began vacationing again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Covid Isn’t Finished Messing With Politics
description: Or with the presidency.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I’m trying to keep an open mind — OK, semi-open — about what to think of Joe Biden’s Covid vaccination mandates. I have no problem with the president requiring federal employees to get the shot. I have no problem with businesses large or small requiring the same. Their houses, their rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: The War on Terror Was Corrupt From the Start
description: There were lots of winners of the War in Afghanistan. Defense contractors, for one.
content: The war in Afghanistan wasn’t a failure. It was a massive success — for those who made a fortune off it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Saquon Barkley (and Fans) Returned. But So Did Last Season’s Giants.
description: Despite the return of the Pro Bowl running back, a ballyhooed defense and a readmitted home crowd, the Giants looked listless in a loss to the Denver Broncos.
content: Running back Saquon Barkley dodged and bulled his way to a 5-yard gain on the first play from scrimmage in Sunday’s game between the Giants and Denver Broncos. Barkley, the cynosure of the Giants’ offense until a torn knee ligament kept him out of 14 games last season, seemed whole again, and the home fans at a packed MetLife Stadium leapt to their feet in response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Most Schools Do Not Yet Meet Biden’s Demand for Testing and Vaccines
description: Large districts mostly require masks, and students in the same classroom as an infected person won’t necessarily be told or asked to quarantine.
content: For schools to stay open and safe, President Biden said Thursday, they need to require vaccinations for teachers and staff, regularly test unvaccinated people and have universal masking. So far, many large districts are succeeding at one — masking — but only a minority offer the others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Contrarian’ Goes Searching for Peter Thiel’s Elusive Core
description: In his new book, Max Chafkin narrates the secretive tech mogul’s life and tries to understand what he stands for.
content: After reading “The Contrarian,” Max Chafkin’s judicious biography of Peter Thiel, the secretive and Trump-supporting tech mogul, I was struck by how much Thiel remains a mystery — less of an intriguing enigma than a hollow cipher. This isn’t to fault Chafkin, who is unfailingly diligent in his efforts to narrate Thiel’s life and understand, as far as possible, what he actually believes. But contrarianism tends to be reactive, not constructive; if there’s truly a there there, it risks getting lost in the incessant repositioning of oneself against a fickle discourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Alan Rappeport
title: How House Democrats Plan to Raise $2.9 Trillion for a Safety Net
description: Details of the legislation show higher taxes for companies and the wealthy, but key elements differ from the Senate and White House proposals.
content: WASHINGTON — Top Democrats on Monday released legislation that would raise as much as $2.9 trillion to finance President Biden’s social safety net package through a series of tax changes, including increasing the amount that the wealthiest Americans and corporations pay in taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oriana Skylar Mastro
title: What the U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan Means for Taiwan
description: There are many reasons to fear a Chinese invasion of Taiwan. But  the American pullout isn’t one of them.
content: There are many reasons to fear an impending Chinese attack on Taiwan: Intensified Chinese aerial activity. High-profile Pentagon warnings. Rapid Chinese military modernization. President Xi Jinping’s escalating rhetoric. But despite what recent feverish discussion in foreign policy and military circles is suggesting, the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan isn’t one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Anne Edwards
title: America Can Find a Smarter Way to Help Workers Who Have Lost Their Jobs
description: The structure of unemployment insurance is broken and does little to help those who pay into it.
content: The unprecedented federal action to prop up unemployment insurance system during the pandemic wound down last week even as the pace of hiring in the United States slowed dramatically. The wind-down affected nearly 12 million workers — an estimated 5.1 million self-employed, contract and gig workers and 3.8 million long-term unemployed people who lost benefits completely, and three million who kept benefits but lost the $300 weekly federal supplement — bringing the programs created by last March’s CARES Act and renewed by this March’s American Rescue Plan Act to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Lone Survivor of Italian Cable Car Crash Is Subject of Custody Battle
description: The grandfather of a 6-year-old boy who survived an accident that killed his parents in May is under investigation after taking him to Israel.
content: ROME — A bitter custody dispute has flared over the fate of Eitan Biran, the sole survivor of a cable car crash that killed 14 people including his parents, after his paternal relatives in Italy accused his maternal grandfather of flying the boy to Israel over the weekend without their consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Dana Rubinstein
title: Eric Adams Vows to ‘Welcome Business,’ Calling New York ‘Dysfunctional’
description: Eric Adams, the Democratic mayoral nominee, said that New York will “no longer be anti-business,” drawing a contrast with the current mayor, Bill de Blasio.
content: After nearly eight years of a strained and periodically hostile relationship between the mayor of New York City and its business community, the city’s likely next mayor on Monday delivered a clear message: He wants a reset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Intelligence chief warns that countries besides Afghanistan pose a greater terror threat.
description: “What we look at is Yemen, Somalia, Syria and Iraq for ISIS. And that’s where we see the greatest threat,” said Avril D. Haines.
content: Afghanistan is not the most pressing terrorism threat for the United States, even after the takeover by the Taliban, the Biden administration’s top intelligence official said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: 6 Questions to Ask About Covid and Air Quality at Work
description: Ventilation improvements, adding portable air cleaners and simply opening windows can lower the risk of infection in the office.
content: Whether you’ve already returned to your workplace or will be heading back to the office eventually, it’s a good idea to ask what steps your employer has taken to improve indoor air quality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: How Will Gavin Newsom Survive the California Recall?
description: If he wins, it will most likely be less a vote of confidence than a resounding rejection of the right-wing Republican agenda.
content: LOS ANGELES — In the waning days of the campaign to save his job, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California assessed the stakes as nothing short of saving democracy. The possibility of being recalled from office had woken him to the fragile state of the political system, which he compared to … a Fabergé egg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. Schools Reopen With Joy and Anxiety on ‘Game Changer’ First Day
description: “We’ve got to give this a chance,” said one parent as the nation’s largest school system reopened in full for the first time in 18 months.
content: New York City’s schools reopened on Monday to scenes of joy, relief and anxiety, as roughly a million children returned to their classrooms, most of them for the first time since the country’s largest school system closed in March 2020 because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Case Against ‘Excellence’ at Universities
description: As long as schools brag about their low admission rates, campus diversity initiatives will always be about tweaking around the edges.
content: In the first part of this look at the SATs, I focused on the 10 schools that make up the University of California system and how the stated rationale for abandoning the SAT and ACT might not always match up with reality, in particular when it comes to test preparation courses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Head of Paramount Pictures is ousted as ViacomCBS focuses on streaming.
description: James N. Gianopulos, or “Jim G” as he is known in Hollywood, will be replaced by Brian Robbins, who oversees Nickelodeon.
content: In 2017, Viacom turned to one of Hollywood’s most seasoned and respected executives, James N. Gianopulos, to revive its flatlining Paramount Pictures operation. Mr. Gianopulos quickly stabilized the 1910s-era studio — repairing relationships with filmmakers and producers, building a thriving television division from near-scratch, and restoring Paramount to profitability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gin and Tonics That Change With the Seasons
description: The four “elevated” cocktails at Sona in the Flatiron district make flavor changes for cooler autumn weather.
content: To some, the recipe for a gin and tonic is simple and sacrosanct: gin, high-quality tonic water and lime. But keep an open mind. Johnny Swet, the mixology consultant at the Indian restaurant Sona in the Flatiron district, has created four “elevated” gin and tonics that show the beauty in variation. The No. 3, for example, is made with Jin Jili India Darjeeling Dry Gin, grapefruit, elderflower, mint and star anise; the grapefruit makes it delicious. The fragrant No. 1 combines Hendricks gin with makrut lime leaves, coriander seeds and lime juice, though come fall, it will be varied with apple flavors. For the No. 4, which has cucumber, cumin, fennel and Plymouth Gin, the cucumber will soon be replaced with pear. The popular No. 2 will lose its muddled strawberries for persimmon, but the black peppercorns will still be in the generous balloon glass. Mr. Swet said he wanted to preserve the Indian tradition of gin and tonic, while adding spices and other ingredients used in Indian cooking, and also to make the drinks seasonal, not just for summer. He consulted with the restaurant’s chefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Netflix and ‘The Queen’s Gambit’ dominate the Creative Arts Emmys.
description: Netflix pulled ahead of its main rival, HBO, in the run-up to the prime-time ceremony on Sunday.
content: Fueled by “The Queen’s Gambit” and “The Crown,” Netflix dominated the competition at the Creative Arts Emmy Awards over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In California, Worsening Fires Show Limits of Biden’s Power
description: Despite a visit meant to emphasize his actions on wildfires, experts say there is little the president can do for now to reduce the damage as climate change gets worse.
content: President Biden visited California on Monday to tout his efforts to better protect the state against the raging wildfires that have burned more than two million acres, displaced thousands and pushed responders to the brink of exhaustion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Philbrick
title: There’s a Very Good Reason ‘Washington Slept Here’
description: As president, he went on the road to pull the new nation together.
content: These are troubling and rancorous times. Every day there seems to be another headline about the country’s ever-widening political divide. And it’s not just Democrat versus Republican. Within each party the gulf between the extremes is growing as progressives shout angrily at centrists and Donald Trump’s faithful refuse to tolerate the slightest deviation from his ironbound party line. The word “unprecedented” is often used to describe the level of combative partisanship that has gripped the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Mark Sommerfeld
title: Curtains Up! How Broadway Is Coming Back From Its Longest Shutdown.
description: Determined to reopen, crews are dusting off spotlights, dancers are relearning steps, and everyone is testing, testing, testing as theater seeks to rebound from the devastating pandemic.
content: Broadway is back. Or so it hopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Parents Were Duped, Their Lawyers Say in Start of College Admissions Trial
description: The first parents to face trial in the Operation Varsity Blues scandal are casting blame both on Rick Singer, the admissions consultant, and the overall process.
content: BOSTON — During opening statements on Monday, the defense lawyers for Gamal Abdelaziz and John Wilson made clear that their clients — the first parents to face trial in the sprawling college admissions scandal — would not be the only ones up for judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Urged to Reject Mississippi’s Attack on Roe v. Wade
description: In a new brief in a major abortion case, a clinic and a doctor asked the court to strike down a state law largely banning the procedure after 15 weeks of pregnancy.
content: WASHINGTON — Abortion providers in Mississippi urged the Supreme Court on Monday to reaffirm Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that established a constitutional right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Through 3 Whites, the Art of Blending Wines
description: Different grape varieties are not the only things that winemakers put together. In some form or other, most wines are compositions.
content: Smart wine producers have long understood the virtues of composing blends of different grapes. What one variety might lack in color, tannins, acidity or flavor, could be provided by another, or a third or fourth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: President Biden has erased billions in student debt, but progressives want more.
description: More than 500,000 student borrowers — with nearly $10 billion in student loan debt — had their loans erased this year, Stacy Cowley reports for The New York Times.
content: More than 500,000 student borrowers — with nearly $10 billion in student loan debt — had their loans erased this year, Stacy Cowley reports for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Here’s how in-person teaching is playing out across the U.S.
description: School reopenings tend to do well in areas with high vaccination rates, but the picture is very different for schools in areas with lower rates.
content: New York City public schools are reopening at a time when some schools in other states are already several weeks into in-person teaching. Some districts seem to be doing well, but others are contending with mass outbreaks, hospitalizations and several reported deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Nick Cumming-Bruce and Christina Goldbaum
title: A Million Afghan Children Could Die in ‘Most Perilous Hour,’ U.N. Warns
description: The international community pledged more than $1 billion in emergency aid as millions of Afghans risk running out of food just as winter sets in.
content: Millions of Afghans could run out of food before the arrival of winter and one million children are at risk of starvation and death if their immediate needs are not met, top United Nations officials warned on Monday, putting the country’s plight into stark relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: In an Ancient Greek Port, a New Cultural Hub
description: The city of Piraeus, just outside Athens, is becoming a haven for galleries and design studios attracted by its abundant warehouses and growing creative community.
content: On an exceptionally hot July evening, a crowd was mingling and drinking wine at an art opening on Polidefkous Street. An unassuming thoroughfare lined with low-slung ship-repair and metal workshops in Piraeus, the industrial port city on Athens’s southeast side, it is not a place where galleries have historically set up shop. But despite the derelict-looking buildings and the distance from Syntagma Square, the capital’s stately center, a 25-minute taxi ride away, the scene — like one from Martin Scorsese’s 1985 film, “After Hours,” which depicts the gritty but heady SoHo, Manhattan, of its time — exuded a zeitgeist-y glamour. A sense of possibility filled the air. Indeed, Rodeo, the night’s gathering spot and one of the most respected and progressive contemporary galleries in the greater Athens area, is among a handful of creative forces that are transforming the Agios Dionysios district of Piraeus, not far from the ferry docks, into one of the capital’s most exciting cultural destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Sabo, the guerrilla street artist, gives the Elder campaign a push on the Sunset Strip.
description: The billboard had been covered with sheets on which Larry Elder’s surname had been painted in large block letters with an image of California.
content: The Sunset Strip in Los Angeles awoke on Monday to a hijacked billboard whose ad for the Netflix series “Lucifer” had been covered with one for Larry Elder, the conservative radio host and lead challenger in the campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Akilah Townsend
title: Can a Green-Economy Boom Town Be Built to Last?
description: The race to make electric vehicles is turning some places into winners. Normal, Ill., is one of them. But it has seen good times go sour in the past.
content: NORMAL, Ill. — When he bought a construction contractor called Weber Electric in 2018, Josh Mosier inherited about 20 employees. By the end of the next year, he was up to about 100 employees. By the spring of 2021, the number was over 225.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Art Metrano, Actor and Comic Once Felled by an Accident, Dies at 84
description: He had built a career in stand-up comedy and in film and TV, but a fall from a ladder left him with a personal struggle.
content: Art Metrano, a comedian and actor who appeared in more than 120 television shows and films, including the “Police Academy” movies, before a fall from a ladder left him severely injured, an ordeal he turned into a one-man show he performed all over the country, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Aventura, Fla. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s a Day of Firsts in N.Y.C. Schools, and Here
description: In a milestone moment, New York City’s one million schoolchildren are expected back in class today.
content: It’s Monday. Today is the first day of school in New York City. And it’s the first day of our new format for New York Today, with a new look and a new writer — me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: In California, Republicans Struggle to Expand the Recall’s Appeal
description: California has not been as progressive lately as its reputation would suggest. Yet Republicans have had trouble breaking the recall out of the fringe.
content: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — The small faction of Californians who still call themselves Republicans did something seemingly impossible when they forced Gavin Newsom, the Democratic governor of America’s largest Democratic state, to face voters in a recall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sophie Kasakove
title: Louisianans, still recovering from Ida, brace for yet more rain.
description: Some people remain without power from the previous storm. “We don’t need another one,” one resident said.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Even as blue tarps cover damaged roofs across Louisiana and more than 100,000 people remain without power, a new tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to bring more wind and rain, most likely slowing the state’s recovery from Hurricane Ida and threatening residents who are already vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Lagging vaccinations in the U.S.
content: As of Thursday, the U.S. ranks last among the Group of 7 nations for the percentage of its population that has received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, just behind Japan. Some 62.16 percent of Japanese people were at least partly vaccinated, compared to 61.94 percent of Americans. Canada leads the rankings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: flout
description: This word has appeared in 85 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Students Be Allowed to Miss School for Mental Health Reasons?
description: New laws in several states allow children and adolescents to declare a mental health day. Is this a good trend? Do you wish your school gave you the option?
content: Several states, including Arizona, Oregon and Virginia, have recently passed bills that allow students to miss school to take care of their mental health, efforts that were often supported or led by students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Prince Andrew Seeks to Block Epstein Accuser’s Lawsuit
description: In the first hearing in the closely watched case, lawyers for the Duke of York argued that the lawsuit was baseless and legally dubious.
content: A lawyer for Prince Andrew, who was sued last month by a woman accusing him of sexually abusing her when she was a minor, said in a Manhattan court on Monday that the lawsuit was likely to be invalid under the terms of an earlier confidential settlement — one that the prince’s lawyers have said the woman reached with Jeffrey Epstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Two Golden Slams in One Day
description: The wheelchair tennis stars Diede de Groot and Dylan Alcott each added a fourth major championship to the Paralympic titles they won this year.
content: The tennis Grand Slam is so rare that only five players can claim one, and no player at all has achieved the feat since 1988. The Golden Slam, winning all four majors and a gold medal in the same year, is nearly impossible. Only Steffi Graf had ever done it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain Prepared for a Jobs Crisis, Just Not the One It Got
description: Instead of a surge in unemployment, businesses are struggling to fill positions, presenting a new risk to the pandemic recovery.
content: Empty beer taps in pubs, supermarkets low on Diet Coke, milkshakes missing at McDonald’s: It seems each new day in Britain brings a new notice of scarce products and services as businesses are waylaid by the country’s shortage of truck drivers and other workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: New York Fashion Week: Day 6
description: Introducing a duffel bag by Telfar, and a new TV channel to fight the bots.
content: On Sunday, Telfar, the rebellious anti-fashion-with-a-capital-F brand, held a news conference to announce its latest project, Telfar TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: For Afghan Refugees, a Mix of Luxury and Trauma at Albania’s Beach Resorts
description: Albania, which has committed to taking in up to 4,000 refugees from Afghanistan, is housing several hundred in resorts on the Adriatic coast.
content: SHENGJIN, Albania — The medical student, in a trauma-induced trance after a week under Taliban rule and three days of terror waiting for a flight out of Kabul’s airport, looked out the window on her first day at her new home and saw the Statue of Liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Beachy Fare You Can Cook Year-Round
description: Helene Henderson’s latest book, “Malibu Farm: Sunrise to Sunset,” features a host of breezy recipes that conjure sunshine.
content: Is beach season over? Not if you delve into “Malibu Farm Sunrise to Sunset,” the enthusiastic, lavishly photographed new cookbook from Helene Henderson, an owner of the waterfront Malibu Farm restaurants in California, Hawaii and elsewhere, including in New York on Pier 17 in the seaport district. The book, which tells the story of the restaurants, offers easy fare, often vegetable-forward and suitable for outdoor dining, like delicata squash baked with red lentils, a simple flat omelet with a salad plopped on top, and a salad that beckons fall with kale, apples and brussels sprouts. Her grilled mahi mahi with black olive vinaigrette is not the only fish recipe that calls for a mayonnaise or aioli coating to prevent sticking. Ms. Henderson is a native of Sweden, so she is not shy about using creamy sauces like the mustard one for sheet pan chicken breasts, and even in vegetarian recipes like mashed cauliflower with a browned cheese topping. There’s also a chapter, mostly with recipes for sweets, about fika, the Swedish coffee equivalent of teatime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: What role did the Sturgis Rally play in South Dakota’s outbreak?
description: As the Delta variant spreads widely, and as Americans yearn to go back to normal, health experts have debated the public health risks of large outdoor events and music festivals.
content: Daily reports of new coronavirus cases grew tenfold in South Dakota in August, with the worst outbreaks concentrated in the western part of the state. Hospitalizations have increased swiftly in the last few weeks. National Guard soldiers were dispatched to aid with testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Keepnews
title: George Wein, Jazz Festival Trailblazer, Is Dead at 95
description: He brought jazz (and later folk music) to Newport, R.I., and made festivals as important as nightclubs and concert halls on jazz musicians’ itineraries.
content: George Wein, the impresario who almost single-handedly turned the jazz festival into a worldwide phenomenon, died on Monday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Biden Outlines a Plan for Cleaner Jet Fuel. But How Clean Would It Be?
description: Some biofuels may contribute to greenhouse gas emissions in ways that can significantly reduce, and sometimes offset, their advantages over fossil fuels, studies have shown.
content: At first glance, it’s a big step forward in curbing climate change. In a deal announced Thursday, the Biden administration and the airline industry agreed to an ambitious goal of replacing all jet fuel with sustainable alternatives by 2050, a target meant to drive down flying’s environmental toll.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: G.O.P. Seethes, But Every State Requires Shots
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 13, 2021.
content: “Throughout history, states have imposed vaccine mandates. It’s always a little noisy and uncomfortable in the period of time when it’s being done, and then people get vaccinated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In Review, Top F.D.A. Scientists Question Imminent Need for Booster Shots
description: An article, written with other vaccine experts, put the regulators at odds with key federal health officials, including Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
content: WASHINGTON — Two departing Food and Drug Administration regulators argued in a review published Monday that none of the data on coronavirus vaccines so far provided credible evidence in support of booster shots for the general population. Their assertion revealed significant disagreement between career scientists at the agency and top Biden health officials, who have already started planning a broad booster campaign for this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Richard Powers Speaks For the Trees
description: His Pulitzer-winning novel, “The Overstory,” left him so drained that he didn’t know whether he would write again. His new book, “Bewilderment,” came to him when he imagined a child talking to him in a forest.
content: TOWNSEND, Tenn. — On a cool, rainy morning in August, the novelist Richard Powers was in one of his favorite hiding places, a tiny pebble cove along a mountain stream in the Great Smoky Mountains. He has spent countless hours here, writing in his electronic notebook, swimming in the frigid churn until his limbs are numb and staring up at the canopy of alders, sycamore, beech, eastern white pine, hemlock, pawpaw and maple that has become as familiar to him as his own living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sona Patel
title: How do you vote in the recall? Here’s what you need to know.
description: If you missed the deadline to register to vote in the recall election, don’t worry. You can still register on Sept. 14.
content: More than 35 percent of California’s active, registered voters have already cast their ballots, and early voting is underway in several counties. If you missed the deadline to register to vote in the recall election, don’t worry. You can still register on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: On a Rerouted Road Trip, Aaron Rodgers Looked Disoriented
description: The Packers quarterback was intercepted twice in a lackluster showing, while the Saints’ Jameis Winston threw five touchdown passes to take down the Packers.
content: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Saints’ home game that was scheduled to be held Sunday amid climate-controlled pandemonium in New Orleans was instead staged in dryer-vent conditions in north Florida before hordes of fans wearing foam blocks of cheese on their heads — and yet somehow all that seemed downright normal compared to what was transpiring on the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake’s ‘Certified Lover Boy’ Opens With the Year’s Biggest Week
description: The rapper’s latest album debuted with the equivalent of 613,000 sales in the United States, easily beating Kanye West’s total of 309,000 just one week ago.
content: All year long, Drake has teased his fans with a new album, which he said early on would be called “Certified Lover Boy.” It was sure to be a hit, but how big? For Drake, a titan of the streaming era — who over the last week has been facing off against Kanye West — the stakes were high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Defends Deadly Drone Strike in Kabul
description: A New York Times investigation, with video analysis and interviews at the site, has cast doubt on the U.S. military’s account.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon continued to assert on Monday that the last U.S. drone strike in Afghanistan was necessary to prevent an attack on American troops, despite a New York Times investigation that raises doubts about the military’s version of events, including whether explosives were in the vehicle that was blown up and whether the driver had a connection to the Islamic State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A New Company With a Wild Mission: Bring Back the Woolly Mammoth
description: With $15 million in private funding, Colossal aims to bring thousands of woolly mammoths back to Siberia. Some scientists are deeply skeptical that will happen.
content: A team of scientists and entrepreneurs announced on Monday that they have started a new company to genetically resurrect the woolly mammoth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: John Kerry: Delaying U.N. Climate Summit Would Be a ‘Huge Mistake’
description: On a trip through India, Mr. Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, said the global climate summit must be held in November despite concerns about the pandemic.
content: NEW DELHI — John Kerry, the United States envoy for climate change, said Monday that postponing a major United Nations summit on global warming set for November in Scotland would be a “huge, huge mistake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: More ‘Murder Hornets’ Are Being Found and Destroyed
description: Officials hunting the Asian giant hornet in Washington State have so far destroyed three nests, and plan to eradicate a fourth — very carefully.
content: Entomologists in Washington State have so far this year destroyed two nests of the Asian giant hornet — nicknamed the “murder hornet” — and they are planning to eradicate another nest as they try to wipe out the insects, an invasive species that can massacre honeybees and that first appeared in the Pacific Northwest in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge at Guantánamo Says 9/11 Trial Start Is at Least a Year Away
description: The judge set out the timeline while rejecting two defense challenges that he was unqualified and should suspend the proceedings until he was up to speed.
content: FORT MEADE, Md. — The new judge presiding in the Sept. 11, 2001, case at Guantánamo Bay said on Monday that the trial of the five men accused of plotting the attacks would not begin for at least another year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Schools in New York City fully reopen after 18 months of pandemic restrictions.
description: Almost all of the nearly one million students in the public system are returning to class on Monday.
content: New York City’s classrooms reopened on Monday to roughly a million children, most of whom were returning for the first time since the United States’ largest school system closed in March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Kaycee Moore, Actress in Black Directors’ Seminal Films, Dies at 77
description: She explored her characters’ inner lives in movies like “Killer of Sheep” and “Bless Their Little Hearts,” independent works that grew out of the L.A. Rebellion movement.
content: Kaycee Moore, whose nuanced acting documented Black American life in movies by a group of young, Black independent directors in Los Angeles in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Aug. 13 at her home in Kansas City, Kan. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Ephrat Livni and Michael Corkery
title: Phony Walmart News Release Signals a Crypto Pump-and-Dump Scheme
description: Digital currencies briefly jumped in value after a fake release said the retailer would start accepting the little-used Litecoin.
content: The news release went out at 9:30 a.m. Monday, just as the U.S. stock market opened. It claimed to be from Walmart and had some big news for the cryptocurrency industry: The nation’s largest retailer would soon begin accepting payment in Litecoin, a digital currency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Recap Season 5, Episode 9: A Prince Among Thieves
description: Axe continues to let his emotions lead his decisions. And now the consequences are teaming up to take him down.
content: “He’s not dead till I say he’s dead,” says Bobby Axelrod of his decabillionaire rival, Mike Prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacqueline Mroz
title: A Medical Career, at a Cost: Infertility
description: Physicians are raising awareness of the reproductive toll that work stress, long hours, sleep deprivation and years of training can exact.
content: From the start, Dr. Ariela Marshall, a hematologist at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, proceeded with the conviction that if she worked harder, longer and better, she would succeed. And she did: She graduated as high school valedictorian, attended an elite university and was accepted into a top medical school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Shain
title: How to Stay Safe During a Flash Flood
description: Fast rising water can be deadly. Here’s what to do if you’re caught off guard, and how to prepare for a future event.
content: When the remnants of Hurricane Ida pummeled the East Coast earlier this month, bringing heavy rains in a short period of time, dozens of people died as rushing water deluged basement apartments and overtook cars. Flash floods can develop quickly, within hours or even minutes; and they often catch people off guard, killing an average of 88 people in the United States each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC says oil demand will exceed prepandemic levels in 2022.
description: Rising demand for oil, especially in China and India, will outweigh the increasing appeal of electric cars and growth in renewable energy next year, the oil cartel said.
content: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said on Monday that demand for oil was expected to rebound above prepandemic levels next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Tom Ford and the Mini-Series That Was New York Fashion Week
description: What part was most worth watching? Will it be renewed?
content: “New York Fashion Week: The Return” came to a wannabe happy ending like a Ryan Murphy mini-series: in a discorama shower of glitz and Technicolor, with very high production values and a star-studded cast that disguised a questionable story line, leaving open the option to renew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: As Senate Democrats return to Washington, divisions remain over a spending bill.
description: House Democrats have been working to coalesce around details of the proposal, including releasing their opening proposal on Monday.
content: Senate Democrats returned from their summer recess on Monday to confront intraparty divisions over the scope and structure of a $3.5 trillion economic policy bill, as the House races to finish cobbling together the package in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Game Theory Says About China’s Strategy
description: The classic 'salami slicing' tactic is to move against a foe in small increments, staying below the threshold that will provoke a response.
content: On March 19, 1956, The New York Times carried an interview with Matyas Rakosi, who was described as “Hungary’s ebullient Communist boss.” Rakosi said that his enemies had accused him of using “salami tactics,” that is, cutting away all opposition slice by slice. He didn’t deny it: “That is the job of any good political party — including the Communists,” Rakosi said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Zero-Proof Bubbly for Any Celebration
description: Semblance, made from chardonnay grapes, pairs nicely with food and delivers a zip of carbonation.
content: When it comes to alcohol-free drinks, a rapidly growing category, the carbonated ones are the most successful. That’s why some of the beers are quite enjoyable. The bubbles often balance the lack of alcohol; without them the products can taste flat. That goes for wine, too. A newcomer, Semblance — a sparkler made with chardonnay grapes harvested from California vineyards in coastal areas — is dry, lightly fruity and pleasant on its own or to savor with a meal. Drinkers won’t miss the alcohol, and it has a winy quality. Traditional winemaking practices, including fermentation in stainless steel tanks, make the base wine. The alcohol is removed using low-temperature vacuum steam distillation, often called spinning cone technology, said to maintain the character of the grapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: After a Summer Without Butterflies, I Cling to What Endures
description: The ecosystem in my own yard  is showing signs of both trouble and hope.
content: NASHVILLE — How ragged we are now, dragging summer behind us like an old blanket we can’t set down. The homicidal heat of August has given way to the merely cruel heat of mid-September, but we are done with it even so. Everyone is cross, and not just the people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: What did the Met Gala look like last time around?
description: The last time the world had a Met Gala was in 2019, and the theme was “Camp: Notes on Fashion.”
content: The last time the world had a Met Gala was in 2019, and the theme was “Camp: Notes on Fashion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Frost
title: Teaching the 26th Amendment With The New York Times
description: Fifty years ago, 18- to 20-year-olds were guaranteed the right to vote. This teaching resource uses primary sources to help students explore the history and significance of this important expansion of voting rights.
content: Note to our audience: Most of our Lessons of the Day include warm-up activities, critical thinking questions and going-further activities that are written directly to students. Occasionally, however, we create a more in-depth exploration of a particular theme intended to inspire teachers, as we have done here. Have a look and tell us what you think!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: ‘We Did Not Inherit a Plan’: Blinken Is Grilled in Congress Over Afghanistan Exit
description: At least two Republicans demanded the resignation of Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken as he defended the U.S. withdrawal and sought to shift some blame for the chaos to the Trump administration.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday that there was no way to predict how quickly Afghanistan would fall to the Taliban and no evidence that extending the U.S. troop presence could have stabilized the country, in a resolute defense of the American withdrawal last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How to Age Gracefully
description: Inspired by a new book, “Stupid Things I Won’t Do When I Get Old,” I’m taking stock of my life and deciding what I need to reconsider.
content: The day after my 80th birthday, which overflowed with good wishes, surprises and Covid-safe celebrations, I awoke feeling fulfilled and thinking that whatever happens going forward, I’m OK with it. My life has been rewarding, my bucket list is empty, my family is thriving, and if everything ends tomorrow, so be it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Seeing Double With Jasper Johns
description: Two major museums teamed up for “Mind/Mirror,” only to realize they disagreed. Alike yet different, the two shows offer a revelatory look at America’s most famous living artist.
content: On a recent Saturday morning, I arrived at the stone house in Sharon, Conn., and found Jasper Johns outside on the lawn, tending to a massive oak tree. An infestation of gypsy moths was visible on the trunk; gauzy deposits of tiny eggs were imperiling the tree’s health. Johns, who was dressed neatly in khaki pants, a turquoise linen shirt and a pair of heavy yellow gloves, was using his hands to scrape the eggs off the bark. The moths’ gray wings fluttered wildly as they tumbled to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: When Matt and Ben Met Nicole: How They Came to Write ‘The Last Duel’
description: For their first writing reunion since “Good Will Hunting,” Ben Affleck and Matt Damon collaborated with the writer-director Nicole Holofcener on a period drama.
content: It’s been nearly 25 years since Matt Damon and Ben Affleck wrote and starred in “Good Will Hunting,” and cemented the kind of Hollywood partnership where one name is rarely spoken without the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Edmund Lee
title: Fox buys TMZ from WarnerMedia, deepening its ties with the gossip brand.
description: Fox already broadcasts TMZ programs on some of its cable channels.
content: Fox Corporation announced on Monday that it had bought the celebrity gossip brand TMZ from AT&T’s WarnerMedia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Courting moderates, House Democrats stop short of proposing the most aggressive plans to tax the rich.
description: The House Ways and Means Committee focused on traditional ways of raising revenue to pay for the party’s social policy bill — by raising tax rates on income.
content: House Democrats’ plans to raise taxes on the rich and on profitable corporations stop well short of the grand proposals many in the party once envisioned to tax the vast fortunes of tycoons like Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk — or even thoroughly close loopholes exploited by high-flying captains of finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Billie Eilish Sets a Condition for Her Dress: No More Fur
description: The story behind the beige-carpet look.
content: In the context of red carpets, it may seem strange to imagine that wearing a ball gown is a risky choice. But that’s how Billie Eilish saw it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Imposes Limits on Oversight of Local Police
description: The changes address longstanding requests of police departments, who had said that monitors overseeing policing overhauls needed more accountability.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department will curb the power of the monitors who oversee local police departments carrying out federally mandated reform plans, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland told the nation’s law enforcement officers on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel del Valle
title: Why Use a Dictionary in the Age of Internet Search?
description: Dictionaries reward you for paying attention, both to the things you consume and to your own curiosity.
content: I can’t remember how old I was when I first learned the words denotation (the definition of a word) and connotation (the suggestion of a word). But I do remember feeling a little betrayed by the idea that there was a whole layer of language that couldn’t quite be conveyed through a dictionary. Like most young people, I enjoyed learning but thought of it as something I would eventually be done with. At some age, I assumed, I would need to know everything. Understanding the nuances of language seemed like an obstacle to that goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Sheppard
title: Banned in Her Home Country, Wendy Guerra Writes of a Lost Cuba
description: In “I Was Never the First Lady,” the protagonist sets out to find the mother who abandoned her, and Cuba, long ago.
content: I WAS NEVER THE FIRST LADY By Wendy GuerraTranslated by Achy Obejas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Union Veteran Takes Over at Emily’s List as Abortion Fights Loom
description: Laphonza Butler, a labor leader turned strategist, will become the first woman of color — and the first mother — to lead the Democratic fund-raising powerhouse.
content: Emily’s List, the fund-raising powerhouse that has helped elect hundreds of women who support abortion rights, has chosen Laphonza Butler, a former union leader and well-connected Democratic strategist in California, as its next president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: For N.B.A. referees, agreeing to a vaccine mandate, a rarity in U.S. sports, was ‘not that difficult.’
description: Late last month, the N.B.A. sent out a short news release announcing an agreement with the union representing the league’s referees to mandate Covid-19 vaccines. It stipulated that all referees must to be fully vaccinated to work games, including “recommended boosters.”
content: Late last month, the N.B.A. sent out a short news release announcing an agreement with the union representing the league’s referees to mandate Covid-19 vaccines. It stipulated that all referees must to be fully vaccinated to work games, including “recommended boosters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
title: Abortion Is No Longer a Crime in Mexico. But Will Doctors Object?
description: Another battle looms over whether public hospitals will be required to offer the procedure.
content: MEXICO CITY — As soon as the nurse found out that she had an abortion at home, Fernanda García knew she was in danger. The nurse began yelling that she was a criminal, that what she had done was wrong, that she would be sent to jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Intuit to buy Mailchimp for $12 billion.
description: The deal is part of Intuit’s effort to position itself as a one-stop shop for small and midsize businesses.
content: Intuit, the parent company of TurboTax and QuickBooks, will acquire Mailchimp, a company best known as a provider of email marketing services, the companies announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Norway’s ‘Climate Election’ Puts Center-Left in Charge
description: Global warming and the future of the country’s oil and gas industry dominated the election campaign, yet smaller parties with ambitious approaches on climate fared less well than expected.
content: Voters in Norway ousted their conservative prime minister on Monday, turning instead to a center-left leader following an election campaign dominated by climate change, and the growing contradictions between the country’s environmental aspirations and its dependence on its vast oil and gas reserves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In a new review, some F.D.A. scientists and others say boosters aren’t needed for the general population.
description: The benefits of a third shot for most people are small and are far outweighed by the benefits of using those doses for initial vaccinations, the scientists say.
content: None of the data on coronavirus vaccines so far provides credible evidence in support of boosters for the general population, according to a review published on Monday by an international group of scientists, including some at the Food and Drug Administration and the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The J.&J. Conundrum
description: A guide to whether Johnson & Johnson vaccine recipients should get a booster shot — and how they might do so.
content: We’ve heard the question from friends, family members and dozens of readers: Should people who received the single-shot Johnson & Johnson Covid vaccine be getting a booster shot?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Who are the Republican candidates?
description: Only a handful of candidates have registered any meaningful support in the polls or raised the kind of money needed to run a statewide campaign.
content: Dozens of Republicans are running to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom of California. But only a handful of them have registered any meaningful support in the polls or raised the kind of money needed to run a statewide campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Emily Palmer
title: R. Kelly Sexually Abused Aaliyah When She Was 13 or 14, Witness Says
description: The witness, a former backup performer, said she walked in on the singers as they were engaged in a sex act around 1993, one year before they were illegally married.
content: A former backup performer for R. Kelly testified that she saw Mr. Kelly engaging in a sex act with the R&B singer Aaliyah around 1993, when Aaliyah was only 13 or 14 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: For Basketball Refs, Agreeing to a Vaccine Mandate Was ‘Not That Difficult’
description: The president of the referees’ union said “this innovative vaccine” allows refs to keep working. Other leagues do not have similar agreements with their officials.
content: Late last month, the N.B.A. sent out a short news release announcing an agreement with the union representing the league’s referees to mandate Covid-19 vaccines. It stipulated that all referees must to be fully vaccinated to work games, including “recommended boosters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Barrett says the Supreme Court’s work is not affected by politics.
description: “To say the court’s reasoning is flawed is different from saying the court is acting in a partisan manner,” Justice Amy Coney Barrett said.
content: Justice Amy Coney Barrett said on Sunday that political partisanship plays no role in decision making at the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: When Wes Anderson Comes to Town, Buildings Get Symmetrical
description: For “The French Dispatch,” the filmmakers set up shop in a real French city to create the setting for the movie’s fictional one.
content: What happens when you combine the cinema of Wes Anderson with a charming, historic French city? You get a stylized version of France that highlights the director’s whimsical passions — like centuries-old buildings reframed in symmetric picture-book ways and neighborhoods accented with quaint and colorful accessories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Pinterest Accused of Not Paying Female ‘Co-Creator’
description: In a lawsuit, a woman who said she had helped create Pinterest claimed the founders had agreed to compensate her but never did.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Pinterest went public in 2019, Christine Martinez’s friends sent congratulations. She had worked closely with the founders of the digital pinboard in its earliest days, and her friends thought she would get rich alongside them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Dave Eggers Created the Google-Amazon Mash-Up of Your Nightmares
description: The author dissects the anxieties and discontents of living in a world wrought by tech giants.
content: Imagine a world in which Google and Amazon join together to form an all-knowing corporate juggernaut that could program our every movement. Author Dave Eggers has contemplated such a future in his latest dystopian novel “The Every.” Eggers, who limits his own use of technology to the bare minimum, says he was inspired by the limitless choice of our digital world and the idea of a data-driven tech monopoly that would use “your preferences and algorithmic-determined personality” to help you “become the better version of yourself and the ultimate version of yourself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Apple Issues Emergency Security Updates to Close a Spyware Flaw
description: Researchers at Citizen Lab found that NSO Group, an Israeli spyware company, had infected Apple products without so much as a click.
content: Apple issued emergency software updates for a critical vulnerability in its products on Monday after security researchers uncovered a flaw that allows highly invasive spyware from Israel’s NSO Group to infect anyone’s iPhone, iPad, Apple Watch or Mac computer without so much as a click.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Britney Spears Announces Engagement to Longtime Boyfriend, Sam Asghari
description: In the wake of recent developments in the battle over her conservatorship, the singer announced plans to wed for the third time.
content: Britney Spears announced on Sunday that she was engaged to her longtime boyfriend, Sam Asghari, three months after she told a Los Angeles judge that the conservatorship that has governed her life since 2008 was robbing her of the ability to make personal decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: A Black Woman in Finance Regains Her Agency
description: In Natasha Brown’s slim debut novel, “Assembly,” the social critique matters more than the plot.
content: ASSEMBLY By Natasha Brown
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Kate Conger
title: Under G.O.P. Pressure, Tech Giants Are Empowered by Election Agency
description: New rulings by the Federal Election Commission protect the flexibility of major social media companies to control political content shared on their platforms.
content: When Twitter decided briefly last fall to block users from posting links to an article about Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son Hunter, it prompted a conservative outcry that Big Tech was improperly aiding Mr. Biden’s presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: A small upstate New York hospital will stop delivering babies after 6 workers quit rather than be vaccinated.
description: Seven other staff members in the maternity department at Lewis County General Hospital have not indicated whether they will get their shots, said an official.
content: A small hospital in upstate New York is planning to suspend delivering babies starting in a few weeks because some of its labor and delivery nurses resigned rather than comply with the state’s Covid vaccine mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: California Farmers, Worried About Water, May Be a Force in Recall Vote
description: Many say they favor ousting Gov. Gavin Newsom because of high taxes and restrictions on water use in the current drought.
content: Craig Gordon, the owner of several dairy farms near Los Angeles, is a lifelong Democrat. He supported Senator Bernie Sanders for president, he doesn’t like former President Donald J. Trump and he voted for Gov. Gavin Newsom in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Chablis, From the 2019 Vintage Perspective
description: In this white Burgundy appellation, the vintage character can make all the difference between a distinctive region and a more generic chardonnay wine.
content: Years ago, a friend who loved white Burgundy said to me, “Everybody loves Chablis, but it’s nobody’s favorite.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Vaccination becomes a flash point for celebrities.
description: In a tweet Nicki Minaj, said she had not received the Covid-19 vaccine and would not be attending the Met Gala.
content: The Met Gala’s vaccine requirement has become reason for some celebrities not to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Where Pad Thai Is Just the Beginning
description: The chef Hong Thaimee is serving her pad thai in a new space across the village in Manhattan.
content: Hong Thaimee, the Thai chef who had the restaurant Ngam in the East Village and pop-ups elsewhere, has now established herself in Greenwich Village with a kitchen for takeaway and deliveries, and a restaurant. Pad Thaimee, serving pad thai, the dish for which she is best known, and a version made with zucchini noodles, was up and running at the end of August. The limited menu also includes a gently-spiced green curry fried rice, and fried rice with Chinese broccoli, egg and anchovies. Chicken, shrimp, soft-shell crab, mixed seafood or tofu can be added to any of the dishes. The easily reheated food comes in boxes lined with banana leaves to hold moisture. A vegan Thai menu, only for takeout and deliveries and called Thaimee Blossom, will be available in November. And Thaimee Love, which was a pop-up at 615 Hudson Street, will also open as a regular restaurant, sharing the same kitchen in several weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: They Worked for R. Kelly. This Is What They Saw.
description: Several key witnesses against Mr. Kelly, who is on trial in Brooklyn, still appear loyal to the singer — but their accounts appear to corroborate the accusations against him.
content: R. Kelly and one of his assistants were in a park in Chicago a few years before his 2019 arrest when the singer asked the assistant, Diana Copeland, why she had not acted to prevent one of his girlfriends from packing her suitcase and leaving his home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: All the World in a ‘Slice’ of Art
description: The newest painting by Jasper Johns was inspired by a fan letter from an astrophysicist. Here’s a first look.
content: At 91, Jasper Johns is turning out impressive and touchingly personal work. During the solitary months of the pandemic, he completed a painting titled “Slice,” and a group of related drawings and prints. Likely to be a standout of his upcoming show, “Jasper Johns: Mind/Mirror,” a two-venue retrospective opening Sept. 29 at the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Philadelphia Museum of Art, “Slice” is a large, horizontal and predominantly black oil painting that combines unrelated images of a map of outer space and a human knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Why Our Monsters Talk to Michael Wolff
description: In his new book, the author of “Fire and Fury” continues his specialty: teasing out stories from men in power.
content: It’s early 2019, a few months before Jeffrey Epstein will be arrested on sex charges, and he is sitting in the vast study of his New York mansion with a camera pointed at him as he practices for a big “60 Minutes” interview that would never take place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Why Apple Didn’t Lose in the Epic Games Ruling
description: A judge’s split decision in the lawsuit mostly went in favor of Big Tech.
content: A federal judge’s split decision on Friday in the high-profile case between Apple and Epic Games, which stopped short of declaring Apple a monopoly but said it was anticompetitive, allowed parties on both sides of the argument to claim victory. The ruling also set off celebrations among developers who said the ruling would allow them to avoid Apple’s 30 percent commission on in-app purchases. Spotify, one of those developers, said it was pleased with the ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why does California have recall elections?
description: The election that thrust Arnold Schwarzenegger into power in 2003 was the first time that many Americans heard of a recall. But they have a long history in the U.S.
content: The high-profile election that thrust Arnold Schwarzenegger into power in 2003 was the first time that many Americans heard of a recall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With Crowds Back at the U.S. Open, Young Stars Give Them a Show
description: Novak Djokovic failed to win a Grand Slam, but there was a sense of renewal, exciting new players named Raducanu and Fernandez, and a sense that tennis is in capable hands.
content: To fully appreciate the unmasked roars of 2021 at the U.S. Open, it was best to have experienced the silence and vast empty spaces of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: From shutdown to reopening: Here’s a look at N.Y.C. schools’ trek through the pandemic.
description: Delays, disappointments, false starts and abrupt reversals marked the 18 months of pandemic disruptions for students, teachers, parents and others in the nation’s largest school system.
content: It’s been exactly 18 months since public schools in New York City  shut down because of the rapid initial spread of the coronavirus. Over that time, students, parents and employees in the New York City school system, the nation’s largest, have had to adjust to a series of abrupt changes that disrupted and reshaped the lives of about 1 million children and 1,800 schools in the district, eventually leading to a full reopening on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marvar
title: There’s Amazon Prime, and Then There’s Shipping by Schooner
description: Against the winds of instantaneous everything, a sailboat crew tries to forge a carbon-neutral supply chain between the Hudson Valley and New York City.
content: The clouds swirled, the wind roared and the waves beat at the hull of the schooner Apollonia, but the ship stayed its course down the Hudson River in New York. Captained by Sam Merrett, it was carrying ayurvedic condiments from Catskill; spelt flour, hemp salves and malted barley from Hudson; wool yarn from Ghent; and other local goods for the hundred-mile trip south to New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Companies have questions for President Biden about vaccine mandates.
description: A trade group representing 2,000 brands asked for clarification about how the requirements, which OSHA is expected to introduce, should be applied.
content: A trade group representing some 2,000 consumer brands sent a letter to President Biden on Monday asking for clarification about his announcement last week that all companies with more than 100 employees will soon need to require vaccination or weekly testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jim Tankersley
title: House Democrats’ Plan to Tax the Rich Leaves Vast Fortunes Unscathed
description: The House Ways and Means Committee’s proposal to pay for trillions in social spending leaves wealth gains and inheritances largely alone. It focuses instead on a more traditional target: income.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Monday presented a plan to pay for their expansive social policy and climate change package by raising taxes by more than $2 trillion, largely on wealthy individuals and profitable corporations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: A Cape Cod in Pasadena, a modern farmhouse in Napa and a 1908 Edwardian home in San Francisco.
content: This house is just off California Boulevard, one of Pasadena’s main thoroughfares, and is 10 minutes by foot or five minutes by car from the campus of the California Institute of Technology.
